page.title: 04LIFEBOAT MEMORIES SWANAGE
page.content: During the war a Greek steamer the "Turkia" loaded with grain came ashore in Chapman's Pool. The lifeboat was called out and stayed with the steamer for two nights. Then the sea began to get rougher and the crew had to abandon ship. Twenty-six of them were brought back to Swanage. The rough weather abated the next day, so the crew went on board again. Tugs eventually floated her and towed her into Portland during the weekend. This rescue lasted for seventy-four hours. Many aircraft were shot down over Swanage Bay during the war, although the lifeboat never actually picked anyone out of the sea. The shortest rescue ever was when three ladies were cut off by the tide as the lifeboat was passing. They were rescued within minutes.
